Further info object-82 Value: History of onset, family context, adverse childhood experiences, neurodiversities and mental health family history, school and social functioning
Further info dermatologist object-100 Va:
I would find it hard to know and everyone is different, BDD is not my area of expertise. Generally with unfounded worries like this, escalating requests for reassurance don't tend to help and may even make things worse. The young person is already reassured by others that he looks normal and it doesn't help, why would a dermatologist be different?

On the other hand, reasonably often I do work with young people - particularly neurodiverse young people - who seem to really benefit from 'professional' advice, or are able to use it to start challenging their deeply held beliefs, and for whom this advice does not generalise. Or who find it helpful to test their theories by asking people. So I could believe either if you told me, but I would tend to assume it wouldn't be helpful unless he has an actual skin condition - in fact a dermatologist cannot practically help him.
Guidelines object-94 Value: No but I would look at Nice guidelines as a start

Guidelines object-94 Value: Depends on what emerges as the more likely formulation once more clearly established. Depression and body-dysmorphia are competing hypotheses here. OCD is an outside possibility.
